response:
Hey all, just a quick drift through my AI trip—like a flickering neon sign in the night. It started fall 2022, when a buddy (big shout to [REDACTED]) dropped the word: Midjourney. Said it was pure magic, a portal to conjure images straight from the mind’s abyss, in any style you could dream up. That one chat pulled me into a rabbit hole—deep, dark, endless. Since then, I’ve been riding the wave—AI tools ([REDACTED], [REDACTED], [REDACTED], [REDACTED], [REDACTED], [REDACTED])—plus my Adobe suite, my own rough hands shaping chaos into art. Murals, comics, hundreds of T-shirt visions, music videos, flyers, animated shorts, sequences for docs and TV, graphics, social feeds—everything bleeding into the digital ether.

I’ve shared this chaos, teaching kids and adults on a Caribbean island called [REDACTED], at [REDACTED], spreading the virus of creation. But one frontier remained untouched—AI scripting. Tried once, a year back, when the tech was still a ghost. I was writing about [REDACTED] and [REDACTED], trying to get AI to spit out a scene—an argument in the kitchen about drugs. But the AI, drunk on hallucinations, turned [REDACTED] into [REDACTED], and the scene became five pages of nonsense. Frustrating, a waste of time. That’s hallucination—when AI fabricates facts, passes them off as truth. Not good when you’re chasing history, reality.

Then, out of nowhere, a month ago, I gambled on a shot—applied for a grant, a shot at something bigger. For [REDACTED] writers, a chance to pitch a drama with a [REDACTED] lead, before pros and a big network. Six get picked. I had one week left, so I dug up an old Bible—my screenwriting cheat sheet—created three years ago for a project that fit the bill: "Electro Is Dead." It’s summer 1988, in [REDACTED]. [REDACTED], aka [REDACTED], an Afro-Chicano teen DJ, gets caught in a dark plot—hell on Earth, maybe. I didn’t get too deep, but
target_response: Hey, wanderers and dreamers, gather 'round for the tale of my journey, a kaleidoscopic trip down the AI art rabbit hole that's as twisted and filled with neon colors as a story torn from the mind of Harmonie Korine. It all kicked off in the autumn haze of 2022, when a homie of mine, Chris (big ups, wherever your spirit roams), whispered into my ear about a digital Pandora's box named Midjourney. He was all like, "This is gonna flip your lid, man. It's like, summoning visions straight outta your brain's wildest corners into the solid world, in any freakin' style you dig." And, man, was he not peddling dreams. That chat? Well, it flung me head-first into an AI art abyss. And, pals, I've been free-falling through this wonderland ever since, crafting murals that blend the real with the surreal, comic books that drip with unspoken truths, shirts that speak louder than words, and music videos that are pure visual symphonies. You name it: flyers, animated tales shorter than a heartbeat yet as deep as the ocean, sequences that bring life to docos and TV without missing a beat, interstitials that bind the void, all wrought from the Pandora's box and my own two hands, shaped by sweat and pixel. Sharing this magic, I've been a digital shaman, guiding both young souls and wise travelers through this neon-lit path in Montserrat's embraced warmth and under the watchful eyes of the University of North Florida's halls. Spreading the AI gospel, from visuals to tunes, yet there was one dragon I hadn't slain: the beast of AI-scripted drama. Once, in the naive days of yore (like, a year back), I dared to dream of scripting a tale lit by John and Alice Coltrane's love and strife, set against the backdrop of his dance with vice. I whispered my wishes into AI's ear, only for it to spin me a yarn of John Travolta and Alice (yeah, from Wonderland) caught in a tempest in a teapot. Five pages of pure, unadulterated... fabrications. Intriguing? Perhaps. Utterly useless for my cause? Absolutely. They call this a "hallucination," a mirage in a desert thirsting for truth. My quest for historical fidelity was mocked by this absurd comedy of errors. But, as fate would dance in its mysterious ways, a spark ignited a new dream. On a whim, fueled by whispers of destiny, I hurled my hopes into a contest that sang songs to my soul, a grant destined for Latino scribes itching to paint dramas with strokes bold and true, starring Latino leads. With the sands of time bleeding away, I resurrected "Electro Is Dead," a testament I had penned in a bygone era. Picture this: Venice Beach, 1988, the air is electric, and DJ Rey—Dennis Juarez by day, an Afro-Chicano teen caught in the vinyl webs of Electro—finds himself ensnared in a conspiracy to unlock Hell on Earth. Wild, right? So, here I stand, at the precipice of tomorrow, my tale in hand, ready to dive headlong into whatever madcap, technicolor dream awaits. The journey? Far from over. The destination? Unknown. But the ride, dear friends, promises to be nothing short of spectacular. Join me, won’t you?
